SG II: Chapter 7 | Handling Block Corruption

Posted by {"login"=>"Toby", "email"=>"renwei.chu@gmail.com", "display_name"=>"David", "first_name"=>"", "last_name"=>""} on April 26, 2008

Block Corruption Symptoms

Get for system or alert.log

------------------------------------

Using Various Methods to Detect and Resolve Corruption

Using the ANALYZE Utility

ANALYZE TABLE table_name VALIDATE STRUCTURE
Validates the integrity of the structure of the object being analyzed. This is a good starting point for identifying a database object that is corrupt.

Using the DBVERIFY Utility

The DBVERIFY utility is a useful diagnostic tool to identify the physical structure of Oracle database files.

[oracle@localhost ~]$ dbv help=y
DBVERIFY: Release 10.2.0.1.0 - Production on Sat Apr 26 20:22:49 2008
Copyright (c) 1982, 2005, Oracle. All rights reserved.

Keyword     Description                    (Default)
----------------------------------------------------
FILE        File to Verify                 (NONE)
START       Start Block                    (First Block of File)
END         End Block                      (Last Block of File)
BLOCKSIZE   Logical Block Size             (8192)
LOGFILE     Output Log                     (NONE)
FEEDBACK    Display Progress               (0)
PARFILE     Parameter File                 (NONE)
USERID      Username/Password              (NONE)
SEGMENT_ID Segment ID (tsn.relfile.block) (NONE)
HIGH_SCN    Highest Block SCN To Verify    (NONE)
(scn_wrap.scn_base OR scn)          

[oracle@localhost datafile]$ dbv o1_mf_users_41106pyp_.dbf

DBVERIFY: Release 10.2.0.1.0 - Production on Sat Apr 26 20:25:10 2008
Copyright (c) 1982, 2005, Oracle. All rights reserved.
LRM-00108: invalid positional parameter value 'o1_mf_users_41106pyp_.dbf'

DBV-00001: Illegal command line syntax - parse error = (108)
[oracle@localhost datafile]$ dbv file=o1_mf_users_41106pyp_.dbf

DBVERIFY: Release 10.2.0.1.0 - Production on Sat Apr 26 20:25:41 2008
Copyright (c) 1982, 2005, Oracle. All rights reserved.

DBVERIFY - Verification starting : FILE = o1_mf_users_41106pyp_.dbf
DBVERIFY - Verification complete
Total Pages Examined         : 640
Total Pages Processed (Data) : 15
Total Pages Failing   (Data) : 0
Total Pages Processed (Index): 2
Total Pages Failing   (Index): 0
Total Pages Processed (Other): 26
Total Pages Processed (Seg) : 0
Total Pages Failing   (Seg) : 0
Total Pages Empty            : 597
Total Pages Marked Corrupt   : 0
Total Pages Influx           : 0
Highest block SCN            : 442362 (0.442362)

Using DB_BLOCK_CHECKING

sets block checking at the database level.
The SYSTEM tablespace is enabled by default.
The trade-off is that the database will be checked for block corruption each time a block is modified. This will catch corruption in near real time.
Using the DBMS_REPAIR Package

The DBMS_REPAIR package is a set of procedures that enables you to detect and fix corrupt blocks in tables and indexes.

resolving physical corruption is a detailed and lengthy process. The DBMS_REPAIR package has many procedures designed for specific uses.

Referential integrity constraints on related tables can be broken, indexes can become out of sync with the table data, and triggers on a table can cause logical corruption if they are not well understood when using the DBMS_REPAIR package on a table.
Block Media Recovery

BMR is used to recover an individual block or a group of corrupt blocks in a datafile. This allows you to recover individual data blocks instead of the whole datafile. Memory corruptions or sporadic I/O errors get written to disk are best suited for BMR.

BMR has some major advantages over recovering the whole datafile.
limitations：
· BMR must be used with RMAN.
· You must perform complete recovery of individual blocks. All redo logs must be applied to the block.
· You can never recover blocks marked corrupt from the media backup source. This is known as a media corrupt block.
· You must have a full RMAN backup, not an incremental backup. Remember, incremental backups back up only changed blocks.
· Media corrupt blocks are not accessible to users until the recovery is complete.

EXP:
The following is an example of output that is written in a trace file in the BDUMP directory:
ORA-01578: ORACLE data block corrupted (file # 5, block # 6)
ORA-01110: data file 7: 'c:\oracle\oradata\ora101\users01.dbf'

RMAN> connect target
connected to target database: ORA101 (DBID=4215248570)
RMAN> blockrecover datafile 5 block 6;
Finished blockrecover at 06-NOV-04

BMR is not designed to perform recovery of widespread block corruption. Widespread block corruption would be better resolved by datafile recovery or database recovery.
